contents.title: Guerrilla Public Service - 99% Invisible
contents.description_html: At some point in your life you've probably encountered a problem in the built world where the fix was obvious to you. Maybe a door that opened the wrong way, or poorly painted marker on the road. Mostly, when we see these things, we grumble on the inside, and then do nothing.
contents.description: At some point in your life you've probably encountered a problem in the built world where the fix was obvious to you. Maybe a door that opened the wrong way, or poorly painted marker on the road. Mostly, when we see these things, we grumble on the inside, and then do nothing.

source.title: Guerrilla Public Service - 99% Invisible

contents.title: Guerrilla gardening
contents.description_html: Guerrilla gardening is the act of gardening on land that the gardeners do not have the legal rights to utilize, such as an abandoned site, an area that is not being cared for, or private property.
contents.description: Guerrilla gardening is the act of gardening on land that the gardeners do not have the legal rights to utilize, such as an abandoned site, an area that is not being cared for, or private property.

source.title: Guerrilla gardening - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

contents.title: Brown University 1870R: DIY Urbanism
contents.description_html:
In this seminar we will examine the do-it-yourself (that is, everyday, anarchic, creative, illicit, and autonomous) making of public space and the ways by which individuals and unaligned groups envision and potentially secure spatial justice in an urban contest.
We will achieve this by looking at 1. different forms of capital (economic, social, cultural, symbolic) that contribute to the production of urban space, 2. the fight for democracy, the ‚Äúright to the city‚Äù movement, and other forms of direct action taken against neo-liberal restructuring in cities from Los Angeles to Istanbul, 3. the anarchist ethos and Occupy movement, 4. small-scale and creative forms of transgressive place-making such as the production of graffiti and street art, and 5. vernacular incarnations of Latino urbanism.
The seminar will consist of weekly in-depth discussions of assigned readings and events that help inform our understanding and envisioning of possible urban futures. The seminar is also intended to provide students with an understanding of the concepts, research methods, and theories used in the field of urban studies and other related disciplines within the social science, including cultural geography, sociology, and anthropology.
I expect students to become fully engaged with the course topics and concepts, which includes having to conduct outside and independent research on ideas introduced in the course readings and discussion. In fact, in addition to conducting close readings of the course texts and my own short introduction to each week‚Äôs discussion, bringing in outside readings, examples, ideas, and questions will be crucial to our having a full and productive conversation in the seminar room. It is important that every student taking this seminar contribute in a way that adds to your (and others‚Äô) understanding of the week‚Äôs themes and overall aims of the seminar. Stephano Bloch
contents.description:

	We will achieve this by looking at 1. different forms of capital (economic, social, cultural, symbolic) that contribute to the production of urban space, 2. the fight for democracy, the ‚Äúright to the city‚Äù movement, and other forms of direct action taken against neo-liberal restructuring in cities from Los Angeles to Istanbul, 3. the anarchist ethos and Occupy movement, 4. small-scale and creative forms of transgressive place-making such as the production of graffiti and street art, and 5. vernacular incarnations of Latino urbanism.
	The seminar will consist of weekly in-depth discussions of assigned readings and events that help inform our understanding and envisioning of possible urban futures. The seminar is also intended to provide students with an understanding of the concepts, research methods, and theories used in the field of urban studies and other related disciplines within the social science, including cultural geography, sociology, and anthropology. 
	I expect students to become fully engaged with the course topics and concepts, which includes having to conduct outside and independent research on ideas introduced in the course readings and discussion. In fact, in addition to conducting close readings of the course texts and my own short introduction to each week‚Äôs discussion, bringing in outside readings, examples, ideas, and questions will be crucial to our having a full and productive conversation in the seminar room. It is important that every student taking this seminar contribute in a way that adds to your (and others‚Äô) understanding of the week‚Äôs themes and overall aims of the seminar. Stephano Bloch

contents.title: Critique of Urban Geography (Debord)
contents.description_html: Of all the affairs we participate in, with or without interest, the groping quest for a new way of life is the only thing that remains really exciting. Aesthetic and other disciplines have proved glaringly inadequate in this regard and merit the greatest indifference.
contents.description: Of all the affairs we participate in, with or without interest, the groping quest for a new way of life is the only thing that remains really exciting. Aesthetic and other disciplines have proved glaringly inadequate in this regard and merit the greatest indifference.

source.title: Critique of Urban Geography (Debord)

metadata.description:
**I'm a designer, thinker, writer, and aspiring math-geek** working on developing an understanding of a post-20th-century space so that I can contribute to responsible, equitable, and fun interventions in the built environment.

**My professional work**, which I pour most of my head and heart into, can be found [here](http://workshop.co/projects).

**My personal work**, in general, contextualizes and positions my professional work, and you can find it here, in this place, for now.

contents.title: Little Libraries in the Urban Margins
contents.generated_title: Little Libraries in the Urban Margins
contents.description_html: A few years ago libraries were flying high. I wrote a book about the so-called "third wave" library-building boom of the '90s and early aughts, a boom made possible in part by the dot.com bubble. Today, nearly a decade later, our cities and their libraries find themselves in a very different situation.
contents.description: A few years ago libraries were flying high. I wrote a book about the so-called "third wave" library-building boom of the '90s and early aughts, a boom made possible in part by the dot.com bubble. Today, nearly a decade later, our cities and their libraries find themselves in a very different situation.

source.title: Little Libraries in the Urban Margins

contents.title: Tactical urbanism - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
contents.generated_title: Tactical urbanism - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
contents.description_html: Tactical urbanism is an umbrella term used to describe a collection of low-cost, temporary changes to the built environment, usually in cities, intended to improve local neighbourhoods and city gathering places. Tactical Urbanism is also commonly referred to as guerilla urbanism, pop-up urbanism, city repair, or D.I.Y. urbanism.
contents.description: Tactical urbanism is an umbrella term used to describe a collection of low-cost, temporary changes to the built environment, usually in cities, intended to improve local neighbourhoods and city gathering places. Tactical Urbanism is also commonly referred to as guerilla urbanism, pop-up urbanism, city repair, or D.I.Y. urbanism.

source.title: Tactical urbanism - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

contents.title: Blog
contents.description_html: On Wednesday, November 2nd, SFMTA installed safe-hit posts along their raised bike lane demonstration on Market St. between 12th and Gough streets. While this is a win for SFMTrA, which publicly called for and funded our own safe-hit posts for this stretch only months prior, SFMTA should have solved this problem long ago.
contents.description: On Wednesday, November 2nd, SFMTA installed safe-hit posts along their raised bike lane demonstration on Market St. between 12th and Gough streets. While this is a win for SFMTrA, which publicly called for and funded our own safe-hit posts for this stretch only months prior, SFMTA should have solved this problem long ago.

source.title: SFMTrA

contents.title: Thomassons - 99% Invisible
contents.description_html: Cities, like living things, evolve slowly over time. Buildings and structures get added and renovated and removed, and in this process, bits and pieces that get left behind. Vestiges.

contents.description_html: Software for wardriving is freely available on the Internet, notably NetStumbler, InSSIDer, Vistumbler, or Ekahau Heat Mapper for Windows; Kismet or SWScanner for Linux, FreeBSD, NetBSD, OpenBSD, DragonFly BSD, and Solaris; and KisMac for Macintosh.

contents.title: Anarchist group repairing Portland potholes
contents.description_html: PORTLAND, Ore. -- Masked anarchists are taking the city's pothole problems into their own hands. "I appreciate the effort," said Eric Hollstein. Hollstein lives on Southeast Salmon and his street is littered with one pothole after another. "It's frustrating for sure," he said. "It makes a mess in the street."
contents.description: PORTLAND, Ore. -- Masked anarchists are taking the city's pothole problems into their own hands. "I appreciate the effort," said Eric Hollstein. Hollstein lives on Southeast Salmon and his street is littered with one pothole after another. "It's frustrating for sure," he said. "It makes a mess in the street."

source.title: Anarchist group repairing Portland potholes | KGW.com

contents.title: Guerrilla Drive-Ins: Mobile Urban Movie Theaters Animate Disused Spaces - 99% Invisible
contents.generated_title: Guerrilla Drive-Ins: Mobile Urban Movie Theaters Animate Disused Spaces - 99% Invisible
contents.description_html: Drive-in theaters have come a long way since the outdoor Theatre de Guadalupe in New Mexico first welcomed cars to join seated crowds at screenings in 1915. But decades of growth up through the 1950s and 60s gave way to decline in the 70s and 80s.
contents.description: Drive-in theaters have come a long way since the outdoor Theatre de Guadalupe in New Mexico first welcomed cars to join seated crowds at screenings in 1915. But decades of growth up through the 1950s and 60s gave way to decline in the 70s and 80s.

contents.title: Anarchist group repairing Portland potholes
contents.description_html: PORTLAND, Ore. -- Masked anarchists are taking the city's pothole problems into their own hands. "I appreciate the effort," said Eric Hollstein. Hollstein lives on Southeast Salmon and his street is littered with one pothole after another. "It's frustrating for sure," he said. "It makes a mess in the street."

contents.title: Guerrilla Drive-Ins: Mobile Urban Movie Theaters Animate Disused Spaces - 99% Invisible
contents.generated_title: Guerrilla Drive-Ins: Mobile Urban Movie Theaters Animate Disused Spaces - 99% Invisible
contents.description_html: Drive-in theaters have come a long way since the outdoor Theatre de Guadalupe in New Mexico first welcomed cars to join seated crowds at screenings in 1915. But decades of growth up through the 1950s and 60s gave way to decline in the 70s and 80s.
contents.description: Drive-in theaters have come a long way since the outdoor Theatre de Guadalupe in New Mexico first welcomed cars to join seated crowds at screenings in 1915. But decades of growth up through the 1950s and 60s gave way to decline in the 70s and 80s.
